Chapter 12, Part 5: The Bodhisattva MahÄkÄÅ›yapa
The Bodhisattva MahÄkÄÅ›yapa said:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, the Buddha-nature of sentient beings is like empty space. What is meant by being like empty space?
Good man!
The nature of empty space is neither past, nor future, nor present. The Buddha-nature is also like this.
Good man!
Empty space is not past.
Why is it so?
Because there is no present.
If a dharma is present, one can speak of the past. Because there is no present, there is no past, and also no present.
Why is it so?
Because there is no future.
If a dharma is future, one can speak of the present. Because there is no future, there is no present, and also no future.
Why is it so?
Because there is no present and past.
If there were present and past, then there would be future, but because there are no present and past, there is no future.
For this reason, the nature of space is not included in the three times.
Good son!
Because space does not exist, there are no three times, not because of existence there are no three times.
Like a sky flower, because it does not exist, there are no three times.
Space is also like this, because it does not exist, there are no three times.
Good son!
The absence of things is precisely space, and buddha-nature is also like this.
Good son!
Because space does not exist, it is not included in the three times;
Because buddha-nature is eternal, it is not included in the three times.
Good son!
The TathÄgata has already attained anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, and all buddha-nature and buddha-dharmas are eternally unchanging.
For this reason, there are no three times, just like space.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Good man!
Because space is nonexistent, it is neither internal nor external;
Because the Buddha-nature is eternal, it is neither internal nor external;
Therefore, it is said that the Buddha-nature is like space.
Good man!
It is like the unobstructed place in the world, which is called space.
The TathÄgata, having attained supreme perfect enlightenment, is unobstructed with regard to all Buddha-dharmas, and therefore it is said that the Buddha-nature is like space.
For this reason, I say that the Buddha-nature is like space.
Bodhisattva MahÄkÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
The TathÄgata, Buddha-nature, and nirvÄá¹‡a are not included in the three time periods, yet they are called existent.
Space is also not included in the three time periods, why is it not called existent?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Non-nirvana is called nirvana, non-thus-come is called thus-come, and non-buddha-nature is called buddha-nature.
What is called non-nirvana?
It refers to all afflictions and conditioned phenomena. In order to destroy such conditioned afflictions, it is called nirvana.
Non-thus-come refers to icchantikas up to pratyekabuddhas. In order to destroy such icchantikas up to pratyekabuddhas, it is called thus-come.
Non-buddha-nature refers to all walls, tiles, stones, and insentient things. Apart from such insentient things, it is called buddha-nature.
Good man!
In the entire world, there is nothing that is not opposed to space.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
In the world, there is also nothing that is not opposed to the four great elements, yet one can still say that the four great elements exist.
If space is unobstructed, why can it not be called existent?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
If you say that nirvÄá¹‡a is not categorized as the three times, and space is also like this, this reasoning is incorrect.
Why is it so?

Because nirvÄá¹‡a exists, can be seen, and can be realized. It is form, traces, and words. It exists, has characteristics, is a condition, is a place of refuge, is tranquil, luminous, peaceful, and the other shore. Therefore, it can be called not categorized as the three times.
The nature of space does not have such dharmas, and therefore it is called non-existent.
If there are dharmas apart from such dharmas, they should be categorized as the three times.
If space is the same as existent dharmas, it cannot be not categorized as the three times.
Good man!
It is like worldly people saying that space is called formless, unimpeded, and invisible. If it is formless, unimpeded, and invisible, then it is a mental factor.

If space is the same as a mental factor, it cannot be not included in the three times. If it is included in the three times, then it is the four aggregates. Therefore, apart from the four aggregates, there is no space.
Moreover, good man!
The non-Buddhists say that space is light. If it is light, then it is a form.
If space is a form, then it is impermanent. Because it is impermanent, it is included in the three times.
How can the non-Buddhists say it is not in the three times?
If it is included in the three times, then it is not space. It can also be said that space is permanent.
Good man!
Some people say that space is a place to stay. If there is a place to stay, then it is a form.
But all places are impermanent and included in the three times. Space is also permanent and not included in the three times. If one speaks of places, one knows there is no space.

There are also those who say, 'Space is the sequence. If it is the sequence, it is a counted dharma. If it can be counted, it is included in the three times. If it is included in the three times, how can it be said to be permanent?'
Good man!
If one further says, 'Space is not apart from the three dharmas:
First, empty; second, real; third, empty and real.
If one says emptiness is it, one should know that space is an impermanent dharma.
Why is it so?
Because the place of reality does not exist.
If one says reality is it, one should know that space is also impermanent.
Why is it so?
Because the place of emptiness does not exist.
If one says emptiness and reality are it, one should know that space is also impermanent.
Why is it so?
Because the two places do not exist.
Therefore, space is called non-existent.
Good man!

It is said that space is a conditioned dharma, as it is said that space is created by removing trees and houses, that space is made flat, that space is covered, that space is above, that the color of space is painted, like the great ocean. Therefore, space is a conditioned dharma.
All conditioned dharmas are impermanent, just like a clay pot. If space is so, it should be impermanent.
Good man!
People in the world say that the unobstructed place among all dharmas is called space.
Is this unobstructed place completely existent in all dharmas?
Or is it partially existent?
If it is completely existent, one should know that other places are not space.
If it is partially existent, it is a countable dharma that can be distinguished. If it is countable, one should know it is impermanent.
Good man!
If someone says that unobstructed space combines with existence, and further says that space is in things like fruit in a vessel, both are incorrect.
Why is this?
If it is said to combine, there are three kinds:
1. Combination of different karmas, like flying birds gathering on a tree;
2. Combination of shared karmas, like two rams butting each other;
3. Combination of already combined karmas, like two pairs of fingers combining in one place.
If it is said to be a combination of different karmas, different means there are two:
One is the karma of things, the other is the karma of space.
If the karma of space combines with things, space is then impermanent.
If the karma of things combines with space, things are then not all-pervading. If they are not all-pervading, they are also impermanent.
If it is said that permanent space, whose nature is unmoving, combines with moving things, this is incorrect.
Why is this?ğŸ”½If space is permanent, things should also be permanent.
If things are impermanent, space is also impermanent.
If you say that space is both permanent and impermanent, this is not possible.
If you say that it combines with karma, this is not reasonable.
Why is it so?
Space is said to be all-pervading.

If it combines with karma, karma should also be all-pervading. If it is all-pervading, it should pervade everything. If it pervades everything, it should combine with everything, and it should not be said that there is combination and non-combination.
If you say that it has already combined and combines like two pairs of fingers combining, this is not reasonable.
Why is it so?
Because there was no combination before, and it is combined later.
If there was no existence before and existence later, this is a impermanent dharma. Therefore, it cannot be said that space has already combined and combines.
Like worldly dharmas, which did not exist before and exist later, these things are impermanent.
If space is like this, it should also be impermanent.
If you say that space is in things, like fruit in a container, this is not reasonable.
Why is it so?
Like this, when there was no container before, in what place did space abide?
If there is a place where it abides, then space would be more.
If it is more, how can you say it is permanent, one, and all-pervading?
If space abides apart from space, then other things should also abide apart from space. Therefore, you should know that space does not exist.
Good man!
If someone says that the place where the finger abides is called space, you should know that space is an impermanent dharma.
Why is it so?
The finger has four sides. If it has four sides, you should know that space also has four sides.
All permanent dharmas have no location. Because it has a location, space is impermanent.
If it is impermanent, it is not apart from the five skandhas. One must be apart from the five skandhas, and then it is nonexistent.
Good man!
If there is a dharma that abides due to causes and conditions, you should know that this dharma is called impermanent.
Good man!
It is like all sentient beings and trees and plants that depend on the earth to exist. Because the earth is impermanent, the things that depend on the earth are also impermanent in sequence.
Good man!
It is like the earth depending on water. Because water is impermanent, the earth is also impermanent.
It is like water depending on wind. Because wind is impermanent, water is also impermanent.
Wind depends on space. Because space is impermanent, wind is also impermanent.
If it is impermanent, how can it be said that space is permanent and pervades everywhere?
Because space does not exist, it is not past, future, or present, just like the horns of a rabbit. Because it is a non-existent thing, it is not past, future, or present.
Therefore, I say that because buddha-nature is permanent, it is not included in the three times.
Because space does not exist, it is not included in the three times.
Good man!
I will never argue with the world.
Why is it so?
When worldly wisdom speaks of existence, I also speak of existence. When worldly wisdom speaks of non-existence, I also speak of non-existence.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa said:
World-Honored One!
How many dharmas are possessed by Bodhisattva-Mahasattvas that they do not dispute with the world?
How are they not defiled by worldly dharmas?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Bodhisattva-Mahasattvas who possess ten dharmas do not dispute with the world and are not defiled by worldly dharmas.
What are the ten?

First, having faith; second, observing precepts; third, associating with good friends; fourth, good thoughts within; fifth, being fully energetic; sixth, being fully mindful; seventh, being fully wise; eighth, being fully correct in speech; ninth, delighting in the true Dharma; tenth, having compassion for sentient beings.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who are endowed with these ten qualities do not dispute with the world, and are not defiled by worldly dharmas, like an utpala flower.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, when worldly wisdom speaks of existence, I also speak of existence; when worldly wisdom speaks of non-existence, I also speak of non-existence.
What is meant by worldly wisdom speaking of existence and non-existence?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
If worldly wisdom speaks of form as impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self, up to consciousness being the same,
good man!
This is called what worldly wisdom speaks of as existent, and I also speak of as existent.
Good man!
Worldly wisdom speaks of form as lacking permanence, bliss, self, and purity, and feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are also like this.
Good man!
This is called what worldly wisdom speaks of as non-existent, and I also speak of as non-existent.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

The worldly wise ones are the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, and all sages. If the sages say that form is impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self, why does the Tathagata say that the Buddha's form body is permanent and unchanging?
The worldly wise ones say that things do not exist, why does the Tathagata say that they exist?
The Tathagata, the World-Honored One, speaks like this, why do you say that he does not dispute with the world?
He is not defiled by worldly dharmas?

The Tathagata has already left behind the three kinds of inversions, namely the inversion of thought, the inversion of mind, and the inversion of views. He should say that the Buddha's form is truly impermanent, but now he says it is permanent. How can he be said to be far removed from inversion and not dispute with the world?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
The form of ordinary beings arises from afflictions, therefore the wise say that form is impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self.
The form of the TathÄgata is far removed from afflictions, and therefore it is said to be eternally abiding and unchanging.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa said:
World-Honored One!
How is it that form arises from afflictions?
Good man!
Afflictions are of three kinds, namely the outflows of desire, existence, and ignorance.
The wise should contemplate the faults of these three outflows.
Why is it so?
Knowing the faults, one can then be far removed from them.
It is like a doctor first examining the patient's pulse to know the location of the illness, and then prescribing medicine.
Good man!
It is like a person leading a blind person to a thorn forest, abandoning them, and returning.
The blind person will find it extremely difficult to get out later, and even if they manage to get out, their body will be completely ruined.
Worldly ordinary beings are also like this. They are unable to know and see the faults of the three outflows, and thus follow them.
If one sees in this way, one will be able to distance oneself from [evil deeds]. Knowing the faults, even if one experiences the results of karma, the results will be light.
Good man!
There are four kinds of people:

1. The first is when the act is heavy but the experience of results is light. 2. The second is when the act is light but the experience of results is heavy. 3. The third is when the act is heavy and the experience of results is also heavy. 4. The fourth is when the act is light and the experience of results is also light.
Good man!
If a person is able to contemplate the faults of afflictions, then for that person, the act and the experience of results will both be light.
Good man!
A wise person thinks like this:
'I should distance myself from such defilements, and moreover, I should not commit such contemptible and evil deeds. Why is this?
Because I have not yet escaped the retribution of hell, hungry ghosts, animals, humans, and gods.
If I cultivate the path, I will rely on this power to destroy all suffering.'
When this person contemplates in this way, greed, anger, and delusion become weak.
Having seen the lightness of greed, anger, and delusion, their minds are joyful, and they further think like this:

'In this way, it is all due to the power of the causes and conditions of cultivating the path that enables me to be free from unwholesome dharmas and to be close to wholesome dharmas. Therefore, in the present life, I get to see the right path and should diligently cultivate it.'

This person, because of diligently cultivating the power of the path, is far removed from immeasurable evil afflictions and is also free from the karmic retributions of hell, hungry ghosts, animals, and humans and gods.
Therefore, I say in the sÅ«tras, 'One should contemplate all contaminated afflictions and contaminated causes.
Why is it so?
If a wise person only contemplates contamination but does not contemplate the causes of contamination, then they will not be able to eliminate the afflictions.
Why is it so?
The wise contemplate that contamination arises from these causes. If I now eliminate the causes, contamination will not arise.'
Good man!
Just as that doctor first eliminates the causes of illness, and the illness does not arise.
The wise person who first eliminates the causes of afflictions is also like this.

A wise person should first contemplate the causes, and next contemplate the karmic retribution, knowing that good causes give rise to good fruits, and knowing that evil causes give rise to evil fruits.
Having contemplated the karmic retribution, one should stay far away from evil causes.

Having contemplated the karmic retribution, one should next contemplate the lightness and heaviness of the afflictions. Having contemplated their lightness and heaviness, one should first eliminate the heavy ones. Having eliminated the heavy ones, the light ones will naturally go away.
Good man!

If the wise person knows the afflictions, the causes of afflictions, the karmic retribution of afflictions, and the lightness and heaviness of afflictions, then at that time they will diligently cultivate the path, without stopping or regretting, befriending the virtuous, listening to the Dharma with utmost sincerity, in order to extinguish these afflictions.
Good man!
It is like a sick person who knows their illness is light and can be cured. Even if they get bitter medicine, they take it without regret.
A wise person is also like this. They diligently cultivate the holy path, rejoicing without sorrow, without stopping or regret.
Good man!

If a person can know the afflictions, the causes of afflictions, the retribution of afflictions, the lightness and heaviness of afflictions, and diligently cultivates the holy path in order to eliminate afflictions, this person is not born from afflictions. Form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are also like this.

If one cannot know the afflictions, the causes of afflictions, the retribution of afflictions, the lightness and heaviness of afflictions, and does not diligently cultivate the path, this person is then born from afflictions. Form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are also like this.
Good man!

Knowing afflictions, the causes of afflictions, the fruits of retribution for afflictions, and the relative weight of afflictions, and cultivating the path to eliminate afflictions is precisely the TathÄgata. For this reason, the TathÄgata's form is permanent, and so is his consciousness.
Good man!

Not knowing afflictions, the causes of afflictions, the fruits of retribution for afflictions, and the relative weight of afflictions, and being unable to cultivate the path is precisely an ordinary person. Therefore, the form of an ordinary person is impermanent, and so are their feelings, perceptions, mental formations, and consciousness.
Good man!
The wise ones in the world, all sages, bodhisattvas, and buddhas expound these two meanings. I also expound these two meanings in the same way.
Therefore, I say that I do not dispute with the wise ones in the world, and I am not defiled by worldly dharmas.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, the three with outflows - what are they called the outflow of desire, the outflow of existence, and the outflow of ignorance?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
The leakage of desire refers to the evil thoughts and speculations within, which, due to external conditions, give rise to the leakage of desire.
Therefore, I once said to Ä€nanda in RÄjagá¹›ha:
'Ä€nanda!
You should now accept the verses spoken by this woman. These verses were proclaimed by the Buddhas of the past.'
Therefore, all evil thoughts and speculations within, and external conditions, are called desire. This is called the leakage of desire.

The leakage of existence refers to the evil dharmas within the form and formless realms, and external conditions. Excluding external conditions and internal thoughts and speculations in the desire realm, this is called the leakage of existence.

The leakage of ignorance refers to the inability to understand the self and what belongs to the self, and the inability to distinguish between internal and external. This is called the leakage of ignorance.
Good man!
Ignorance is the fundamental root of all leakages.
Why is it so?

All sentient beings, due to the causes and conditions of ignorance, form concepts and characteristics towards the aggregates, sense bases, and elements, and are called sentient beings. This is called the inversion of thought, the inversion of mind, and the inversion of views. For these causes and conditions, all defilements arise. Therefore, I say in the twelve divisions of the scriptures that ignorance is the cause of greed, the cause of anger, and the cause of delusion.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa said:
World-Honored One!

In the past, the Tathagata said in the twelve divisions of the scriptures that due to the causes and conditions of improper thought, greed, anger, and delusion arise. Why is it now said to be due to ignorance?
Good man!
These two dharmas mutually become causes and effects, and mutually promote each other.
Improper thought gives rise to ignorance, and the causes and conditions of ignorance give rise to improper thought.
Good man!
That which can promote the afflictions is all called the causes and conditions of the afflictions. Being close to such causes and conditions of the afflictions is called ignorance.
Unwholesome thoughts are like seeds producing sprouts. The seeds are the proximate causes, and the four great elements are the distant causes. Afflictions are also like this.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, ignorance is the defilements. How can it be said that because of ignorance, the various defilements arise?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
As I have said, the defilement of ignorance is the internal ignorance.
The arising of the various defilements because of ignorance is the internal and external causes.
If one speaks of the defilement of ignorance, this is called internal inversion, not recognizing impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self.
If one speaks of the causes and conditions of all afflictions, this is called not knowing the external self and what belongs to the self.
If one speaks of the defilement of ignorance, this is called having no beginning and no end, arising from ignorance, the aggregates, sense bases, and elements, and so forth.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, a wise person knows the causes of defilements. What is meant by knowing the causes of defilements?
Good man!
The wise should contemplate, 'What conditions give rise to these afflictions?
What actions create these afflictions?
At what times do these afflictions arise?
When dwelling with whom do these afflictions arise?
Where do these afflictions arise?
What objects, when contemplated, give rise to afflictions?
Receiving whose dwelling, bedding, food and drink, clothing, and medicine do afflictions arise?
For what reasons do lower ones become middling, middling ones become superior, and lower actions become middling, middling actions become superior?'
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate in this way, they will be able to distance themselves from the causes of the arising of defilements.
When contemplating in this way, they will prevent the arising of unarisen afflictions and eliminate already arisen afflictions.
Therefore, I have said in the sutras that the wise should contemplate the causes of the arising of afflictions.
KÄÅ›yapa Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
How can a single sentient being give rise to various afflictions?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Just as various seeds in a single vessel, when watered, each grow their own sprouts,
sentient beings are also like this. Although the vessel is one, due to the causes and conditions of craving, they are able to give rise to various afflictions.
KÄÅ›yapa Bodhisattva said:
World-Honored One!
How do the wise contemplate karmic retributions?
Good man!
The wise should contemplate how the causes and conditions of the contaminants give rise to the hells, hungry ghosts, and animals.

These causes and conditions of the contaminants, even if they attain a human or heavenly body, are still impermanent, suffering, empty, and without self. Within this body-vessel, one obtains three kinds of suffering and three kinds of impermanence.

These causes and conditions of defilements can cause sentient beings to commit the five heinous crimes, receive various evil retributions, sever their wholesome roots, commit the four grave offenses, and slander the Three Jewels.
The wise should contemplate: Since I have already obtained such a body, I should not give rise to such afflictions and receive various evil fruits.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa said:
World-Honored One!
There are uncontaminated fruits, and it is also said that the wise cut off all karmic retributions.
Are uncontaminated karmic retributions included in what is to be cut off?
People who have attained the Way have uncontaminated fruits. If the wise seek uncontaminated fruits, why did the Buddha say that the wise should cut off karmic retributions?
If they are to be cut off, how can the sages now exist?
Good man!
The TathÄgata sometimes speaks of the effect within the cause, and the cause within the effect.
Just as worldly people say that mud is the same as a vase, and thread is the same as a garment, this is called speaking of the effect within the cause.
Speaking of the cause in the effect means that the cow is the water and grass, and the person is the food.

I am also like this. Speaking of the effect in the cause, I previously said in the sutra, 'I go from the mind to the body. Because the body moves due to the mind, I say the mind goes to the body up to the edge of the Brahma Heaven.'
This is called speaking of the effect in the cause.
Speaking of the cause in the effect means that these six sense bases are called past karma. This is called speaking of the cause in the effect.
Good son!
All sages truly have no outflows and karmic effects.
The cultivation and karmic effects of all sages do not produce outflows again, and therefore they are called outflows and karmic effects.
Good son!
When the wise contemplate in this way, they can forever extinguish the karmic effects of afflictions.
Good son!
The wise, having contemplated, in order to sever such karmic effects of afflictions, cultivate the noble path. The noble path is emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness.
Having cultivated this path, one can extinguish all afflictions and their fruits.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
All sentient beings obtain their fruits of retribution from afflictions. As for afflictions, they are called evil. The afflictions born from evil afflictions are also called evil.
Such afflictions are of two kinds:
first, causes; second, effects.
Because the causes are evil, the effects are evil. Because the effects are evil, the seeds are evil.
Like the fruit of the neem tree, because its seeds are bitter, its flowers, fruits, stems, and leaves are all bitter.
It is like a poisonous tree. Because its seeds are poisonous, its fruits are also poisonous.

Causes are also sentient beings, and effects are also sentient beings. Causes are also afflictions, and effects are also afflictions. The causes and effects of afflictions are precisely sentient beings, and sentient beings are precisely the causes and effects of afflictions.
If it is according to this principle, how is it that the Tathagata previously used the analogy of the snow mountains, which also have poisonous herbs and wondrous medicinal kings?
If you say that afflictions are sentient beings, and sentient beings are afflictions, how can you say that there is a wondrous medicine king in the bodies of sentient beings?
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
Countless sentient beings all have the same doubt. You are now able to ask on their behalf and seek an explanation. I am also able to resolve it.
Listen carefully, listen carefully, and consider it well. I will now explain it to you in detail.
Good man!
The snow mountain is a metaphor for sentient beings. The poisonous plants refer to afflictions. The wondrous medicine king refers to pure brahmacarya.
Good man!
If there are sentient beings who are able to cultivate such pure brahmacarya, this is called having a wondrous medicine king in the body.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
How do sentient beings have pure brahmacarya?
Good man!
It is like in the world, from seeds fruits are born. This fruit has the ability to act as a cause for the seed, and there are those that do not.
Those that have the ability to act are called fruit seeds.
If they are unable to act, they are only called fruit and not seeds.
All sentient beings are also like this, all having two kinds:
First, there are those with afflictions as fruit that are causes of afflictions, and second, there are those with afflictions as fruit that are not causes of afflictions.
Those afflictions as fruit that are not causes of afflictions are then called pure pure conduct.
Good man!
Sentient beings contemplate feelings, knowing that they are the proximate causes of all defilements, namely internal and external defilements.
Because of feelings, they are unable to sever all defilements and also unable to escape the prison of the three realms.

Sentient beings, because of feelings, become attached to self and what belongs to self, giving rise to inverted mind, inverted thoughts, and inverted views. Therefore, sentient beings should first contemplate feelings.
In this way, feeling is the proximate cause for all craving. Therefore, the wise who wish to cut off craving should first contemplate feeling.
Good man!
All the good and evil created by sentient beings through the twelve links of dependent arising are all due to the time of feeling. Therefore, I told Ä€nanda:
'Ä€nanda!
All the good and evil created by sentient beings are due to the time of feeling.'
Therefore, the wise should first contemplate feeling. Having contemplated feeling, they should further contemplate, 'What causes and conditions give rise to this feeling?'
If it arises from causes and conditions, from what do these causes and conditions arise?
If it arises without a cause, why does a non-cause not give rise to a non-feeling?
